column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Determine the Genre of a Book
#Text=When a reader looks for a new author to read , he or she usually browses books in genres they enjoy .
#Text=Whether you 're describing your own work or shelving a book at a library , the right genre will help readers find what they seek .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Marketing
#Text=a Book
#Text=with Genre Descriptions
#Text=List possible genres for the work .
#Text=Assuming the book is already complete , you can narrow it down to a subset of possible genres .
#Text=List anything that could plausibly describe a part of the book , even if you think that " romance " or " action " are relatively minor components .
#Text=If you 're not trying to market a book , or you need help with genre definitions , skip down to the next section .
#Text=Look up similar books online .
#Text=If you do n't feel confident about your list of possible genres , look up works you 've read that are similar to the book you 're marketing .
#Text=If several of them are listed under the same genre , chances are your book will fit under that category as well .
#Text=Conversely , if none of the books under " mystery " sound remotely similar to your book , it 's probably a bad fit .
#Text=Track these genres on Amazon .
#Text=Most fiction is sold through Amazon , so its top seller lists provide important information .
#Text=Although publishers conduct more complex analysis , anyone can conduct one test quickly :
#Text=For each genre , compare the top seller lists each week for several weeks .
#Text=If the same books stay in the top 10 for a long time , the genre is slow moving .
#Text=This usually means there 's less competition , but you 'll be fighting for a smaller readership .
#Text=If the list changes rapidly , that genre is fast moving .
#Text=It will take more effort to compete , but the rewards ( potential sales ) are higher .
#Text=Compare genre advertising fees .
#Text=A roundabout but effective way to compare genre success is through advertising fees .
#Text=Web pages such as BookBub advertising prices and Kindle Nation sponsorship tell you how much various sites value different genres .
#Text=Genres with higher costs tend to have more competition , but larger readership for those who rise above the rest .
#Text=BookBub 's stats in particular give you excellent information if you plan to pay for advertising .
#Text=Compare the cost of a featured deal and the effect of the deal ( additional downloads/sales ) to see which genre gives the best bang for your buck .
#Text=Ask for input .
#Text=You have some more information now , and may be able to narrow it down to a smaller list .
#Text=Ask an editor , publisher , agent , or close friend for their input on the decision .
#Text=Consider the target audience .
#Text=Different genres have audiences with different demographics .
#Text=Most readers will assume a romance novel is written for adults , while fantasy novels are more attractive to young adults .
#Text=When you 're deciding between genres , choose one with a main audience you think will enjoy the book .
#Text=If your target audience is not the same as a typical book in your genre 's , clarify with an additional description .
#Text=For example , write " Young Adult Mystery " or " Literary Science Fiction . "
#Text=Choose two or three genres if reasonable .
#Text=Most websites allow you to pick more than one genre to describe a book .
#Text=It 's often best to allow your book to compete in multiple genres or subgenres , such as " Science Fiction Horror " or " War Thriller . "

column1: #Text=Understanding Genre Definitions
#Text=Learn the main realist fiction genres .
#Text=Genre is probably most important for fiction , as many readers use it to discover works they may enjoy .
#Text=We 'll start with realist fiction genres , or stories that are imaginary but theoretically possible :
#Text=Crime has many overlapping subcategories , including mystery , suspense , and the action-oriented thrillers .
#Text=Romance focuses primarily on a love story , and may or may not be erotic as well .
#Text=This can stand alone or be combined with other genres , usually historical or paranormal fiction .
#Text=Historical fiction can be set at any point in the past .
#Text=Large libraries categorize it further by specific times and places .
#Text=The Western is a popular subgenre with its own tropes .
#Text=Action or adventure describe fast-paced tales of danger and exploration .
#Text=It often includes elements from non-realistic fiction , but this is n't fundamental to the genre .
#Text=Categorize speculative fiction .
#Text=These stories could not happen in the real world in the present or past .
#Text=The exact sub-categories are difficult to define , as there is a huge amount of overlap and experimentation .
#Text=Here 's how they 're most commonly arranged , but do n't be surprised if one book could fit into two or three of the following :
#Text=Science fiction tends to focus more on ideas than plot .
#Text=It 's often set in the future or in space , and attributes unusual phenomena to science ( which may or may not be plausible ) .
#Text=Fantasy includes magical or supernatural elements beyond the understanding of science .
#Text=It tends to be plot-driven .
#Text=Horror seeks to terrify the reader .
#Text=While usually grouped in speculative fiction , there are examples of realist horror as well .
#Text=Shelve nonfiction by subject .
#Text=Any book that covers a topic in the real world is nonfiction , from chemistry textbooks to a collection of political speeches .
#Text=You can refer to them just by describing the specific topic , or shelve them in a library with the Dewey Decimal System .
#Text=One popular nonfiction genre is the biography , which describes a historical figure 's life .
#Text=If written by the subject , call it an autobiography .
#Text=Understand age descriptions .
#Text=Many libraries and bookstores have " young adult " or " children " sections with no other labels .
#Text=This is n't technically a genre , but it tells you the subject matter and writing is appealing and appropriate for that age group .
#Text=Coming of age novels describe the transition from childhood to adulthood .
#Text=They 're often aimed at young adults , but not always .
#Text=Tips
#Text=" Literary fiction " is generally considered separate from genre fiction .
#Text=It tends to focus more on thematic elements and high quality of writing than plot .
#Text=In practice ( some argue ) , this label tends to be given to critics ' favorites , even if it could fit into a genre .
#Text=If you 're trying to determine the genre of an existing book , read the blurbs on the back cover , dust jacket , or inside near the front .
#Text=The copyright page often includes categorization information as well .
